data: 1 00:00:08,308 --> 00:00:10,811 (ASIAN BIG BAND MUSIC PLAYING) 2 00:00:18,552 --> 00:00:20,190 (WOMAN SINGING IN MANDARIN) 3 00:00:22,222 --> 00:00:44,444 Ripped by Freaky Colored by novabros 4 00:00:54,855 --> 00:00:56,528 (THUNDER RUMBLING) 5 00:00:56,990 --> 00:00:59,231 (CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYING) 6 00:01:00,394 --> 00:01:02,237 ELEANOR: Be careful of your fingers. 7 00:01:07,668 --> 00:01:08,840 (LUGGAGE THUDS) 8 00:01:09,570 --> 00:01:11,607 (ELEANOR SPEAKING CANTONESE) (lNDISTINCT CHATTER) 9 00:01:11,705 --> 00:01:13,343 (CHILDREN GIGGLING) 10 00:01:17,110 --> 00:01:18,680 (ELEANOR CONTINUES SPEAKING CANTONESE) 11 00:01:22,049 --> 00:01:23,187 (IN ENGLISH) May I help you? 12 00:01:23,750 --> 00:01:25,957 This is the Calthorpe. 13 00:01:26,053 --> 00:01:27,896 Private hotel. 14 00:01:28,021 --> 00:01:30,092 I'm Mrs. Eleanor Young. 15 00:01:30,357 --> 00:01:33,736 I have a reservation. The Lancaster Suite. 16 00:01:33,894 --> 00:01:37,364 We spoke on the phone when I confirmed yesterday. 17 00:01:37,598 --> 00:01:40,374 Sorry, don't seem to have your reservation. 18 00:01:40,934 --> 00:01:42,777 (THUNDER RUMBLING) (DOOR OPENS) 19 00:01:42,869 --> 00:01:43,904 Good evening. 20 00:01:43,971 --> 00:01:47,111 I'm Reginald Ormsby, hotel manager. ls there a problem? 21 00:01:47,941 --> 00:01:49,750 I'm Mrs. Eleanor Young. 22 00:01:49,910 --> 00:01:53,221 My family and I would like to be shown to our suite. 23 00:01:53,413 --> 00:01:55,051 We've had a long flight. 24 00:01:55,315 --> 00:01:57,158 We're fully booked, madam. 25 00:01:57,250 --> 00:01:58,661 You must have made a mistake. 26 00:01:59,152 --> 00:02:02,258 ORMSBY: I'm sure you and your lovely family can find other accommodation. 27 00:02:02,990 --> 00:02:05,664 May I suggest you explore Chinatown? 28 00:02:07,594 --> 00:02:08,902 (FELICITY SPEAKING CANTONESE) 29 00:02:13,133 --> 00:02:15,977 (IN ENGLISH) Please, may I use your phone to call my husband? 30 00:02:16,169 --> 00:02:17,910 It's the least you can do. 31 00:02:18,472 --> 00:02:19,678 Mmm. 32 00:02:20,173 --> 00:02:22,483 (THUNDER RUMBLING) (ELEANOR SPEAKING INDISTINCTLY) 33 00:02:27,681 --> 00:02:31,026 Mrs. Young, I must ask you lo leave or I'll have to call the police. 34 00:02:31,151 --> 00:02:32,630 Please, go right ahead. 35 00:02:32,686 --> 00:02:34,029 (ELEVATOR BELL DINGS) 36 00:02:36,023 --> 00:02:39,027 Lord Calthorpe, my apologies for the disturbance. 37 00:02:39,126 --> 00:02:42,869 Eleanor! I just got off the phone with your husband. 38 00:02:44,031 --> 00:02:46,272 Get the Lancaster Suite ready. Now. 39 00:02:47,768 --> 00:02:49,270 Surely you're joking, sir. 40 00:02:49,670 --> 00:02:50,944 I assure you, I'm not. 41 00:02:51,838 --> 00:02:53,374 LORD CALTHORPE: As of this evening, 42 00:02:53,473 --> 00:02:59,116 my family's long history as custodians of the Calthorpe is ended. 43 00:03:00,280 --> 00:03:03,227 I'm selling the hotel to my dear friends, 44 00:03:03,316 --> 00:03:05,489 the Young family of Singapore. 45 00:03:07,120 --> 00:03:11,296 Meet the new lady of the house, Eleanor Young. 46 00:03:13,060 --> 00:03:14,300 Join me for a toast. 47 00:03:14,361 --> 00:03:15,863 ELEANOR: We'd be delighted. 48 00:03:20,333 --> 00:03:22,813 Do get a mop. The floor's wet. 49 00:03:29,576 --> 00:03:31,078 Get a mop. 50 00:03:33,880 --> 00:03:35,882 (MONEY PLAYING IN MANDARIN) 51 00:04:03,543 --> 00:04:05,181 I'm all in. 52 00:04:06,780 --> 00:04:07,781 (SIGHS) 53 00:04:14,354 --> 00:04:15,697 CURTIS: Fold. 54 00:04:15,756 --> 00:04:16,757 (EXCLAIMS) 55 00:04:17,190 --> 00:04:18,294 (AUDIENCE EXCLAIMING) 56 00:04:18,391 --> 00:04:19,426 Nothing? (LAUGHS) 57 00:04:19,526 --> 00:04:20,630 (AUDIENCE APPLAUDS) 58 00:04:20,727 --> 00:04:22,263 CURTIS: This whole time you had nothing? 59 00:04:23,597 --> 00:04:24,598 RACHEL: All right, so... 60 00:04:24,698 --> 00:04:28,043 How did I beat TA Curtis so very, very badly? 61 00:04:28,301 --> 00:04:31,908 Well, I know for a fact that Curtis is cheap. 62 00:04:31,972 --> 00:04:33,110 (LAUGHTER) 63 00:04:33,206 --> 00:04:38,246 So he's not playing using logic or math, but using his psychology. 64 00:04:38,612 --> 00:04:42,583 Our brains so hate the idea of losing something that's valuable to us 65 00:04:42,649 --> 00:04:46,153 that we abandon all rational thought, and we make some really poor decisions. 66 00:04:46,253 --> 00:04:47,789 So, Curtis wasn't playing to win. 67 00:04:47,888 --> 00:04:49,799 He was playing not to lose. 68 00:04:50,123 --> 00:04:52,660 Here. Put it towards a haircut. 69 00:04:52,893 --> 00:04:54,236 (LAUGHTER) 70 00:04:54,294 --> 00:04:56,331 RACHEL: All right, that's it for today. 71 00:04:56,429 --> 00:05:00,639 Don't forget your essays on conditional probability are due next week. 72 00:05:01,835 --> 00:05:03,405 (MONEY CONTINUES PLAYING IN ENGLISH} 73 00:05:10,644 --> 00:05:12,089 NICK: Yes! 74 00:05:12,779 --> 00:05:14,486 You know what? You can order your own. 75 00:05:14,648 --> 00:05:16,321 Mmm. I'm okay with coffee. Thanks. 76 00:05:16,817 --> 00:05:18,125 Yeah, well, you always say that, 77 00:05:18,451 --> 00:05:20,124 and then you end up eating all my dessert. 78 00:05:20,453 --> 00:05:21,955 I don't know what you're talking about. (CHUCKLES) 79 00:05:22,022 --> 00:05:23,695 'Cause I have, like, a tiny bit. RACHEL: Uh-huh. 80 00:05:23,790 --> 00:05:26,293 Okay. Can we have one more of these, please? Thank you. 81 00:05:28,195 --> 00:05:31,176 So, what about us taking an adventure east? 82 00:05:35,135 --> 00:05:37,137 You wanna get pork buns in the East Village. 83 00:05:37,470 --> 00:05:38,676 That's what it is, isn't it? 84 00:05:38,805 --> 00:05:40,478 (BOTH LAUGHING) 85 00:05:40,540 --> 00:05:42,486 I was actually thinking of further east. 86 00:05:44,010 --> 00:05:45,011 Like Queens? 87 00:05:45,145 --> 00:05:46,317 (CHUCKLES) 88 00:05:46,379 --> 00:05:48,825 Like Singapore. For spring break. 89 00:05:49,316 --> 00:05:50,488 Colin's wedding. 90 00:05:50,817 --> 00:05:52,160 We've been dating for over a year now, 91 00:05:52,219 --> 00:05:55,132 and I think it's about time people met my beautiful girlfriend. 92 00:05:55,622 --> 00:05:57,693 Come on, I'm Colin's best man. 93 00:05:58,058 --> 00:05:59,469 Don't you wanna see where I grew up? 94 00:05:59,793 --> 00:06:02,239 Meet my family, my Ah Ma? 95 00:06:02,362 --> 00:06:04,364 And meet up with that strange college roommate of yours. 96 00:06:04,965 --> 00:06:06,342 Peik Lin. Mmm-hmm. 97 00:06:06,399 --> 00:06:07,400 Peik Lin. She has been begging me 98 00:06:07,701 --> 00:06:08,839 to come visit her, you know. 99 00:06:09,169 --> 00:06:11,843 The universe has spoken. It wants you over there. 100 00:06:13,306 --> 00:06:14,307 Come to Singapore. 101 00:06:14,908 --> 00:06:17,980 I want the whole island to meet the brilliant Rachel Chu. 102 00:06:18,645 --> 00:06:19,749 RACHEL: Aww. 103 00:06:19,913 --> 00:06:21,688 (DRUMS BEATING) 104 00:06:29,089 --> 00:06:30,568 (CAMERA CLICKS) 105 00:07:02,522 --> 00:07:04,058 (CELL PHONES CHIMING) 106 00:07:36,056 --> 00:07:38,935 ELEANOR: "if then you have been raised with Christ, 107 00:07:38,992 --> 00:07:40,938 "seek the things that are above 108 00:07:40,994 --> 00:07:42,940 "where Christ is seated (CELL PHONES CHIMING) 109 00:07:42,996 --> 00:07:44,942 "at the right hand of God. 110 00:07:46,132 --> 00:07:49,079 "Set your minds on things that are above, 111 00:07:49,135 --> 00:07:51,672 "not on things that are on Earth.Â“ 112 00:07:52,138 --> 00:07:55,312 JACQUELINE: Eleanor, is Nicki bringing a girl to Colin's wedding? 113 00:07:55,976 --> 00:07:57,956 My Amanda heard it from her friend Francesca. 114 00:07:58,278 --> 00:08:00,588 Eddie says her name is Rachel Chu. 115 00:08:00,747 --> 00:08:03,250 NADINE: Oh, I thought that Nick was coming alone. 116 00:08:03,416 --> 00:08:05,123 Did you know he had a girlfriend'! 117 00:08:05,618 --> 00:08:08,929 Nick dates many girls. It's hard to keep track. 118 00:08:09,356 --> 00:08:12,337 Amanda knows everyone and she has never heard of her. 119 00:08:13,093 --> 00:08:14,197 NADINE: Rachel Chu. 120 00:08:14,861 --> 00:08:17,774 Maybe she's from the Taiwan plastics Chu family. 121 00:08:17,998 --> 00:08:20,877 If you want, I have a private investigator. 122 00:08:21,134 --> 00:08:22,135 (WHISPERS) Very discreet. 123 00:08:22,435 --> 00:08:25,041 I think we should return 10 the word of God. 124 00:08:26,473 --> 00:08:27,543 ELEANOR: Alix. 125 00:08:29,142 --> 00:08:31,554 Ephesians. Chapter six, verse four. 126 00:08:32,112 --> 00:08:35,525 "Bring up your children in the discipline and instruction of the Lord." 127 00:08:35,615 --> 00:08:37,458 Oh, I do hope she's a good Christian girl. 128 00:08:37,517 --> 00:08:39,656 JACQUELINE: Well, if he's bringing her home, it must be serious. 129 00:08:39,819 --> 00:08:40,820 Exactly. 130 00:08:45,458 --> 00:08:46,835 (CELL PHONE RINGING) 131 00:08:47,060 --> 00:08:49,370 Oh, it's my mum. Do you mind? RACHEL: Mmm, go ahead. 132 00:08:49,462 --> 00:08:51,874 All right. Save me some of that. Okay. 133 00:08:54,300 --> 00:08:56,041 NICK: Hey, Mum, everything okay? 134 00:08:56,336 --> 00:08:59,078 ELEANOR: Does something have to be wrong for me to call? 135 00:08:59,172 --> 00:09:00,913 (CHUCKLES) Yeah, usually. 136 00:09:01,007 --> 00:09:02,077 (ELEANOR LAUGHS SARCASTICALLY) 137 00:09:02,175 --> 00:09:03,245 Very funny. 138 00:09:03,676 --> 00:09:06,657 Are you bringing the girl you're seeing to Colin's wedding? 139 00:09:07,080 --> 00:09:08,184 Hmm. 140 00:09:08,248 --> 00:09:10,524 We were literally just talking about that. 141 00:09:10,583 --> 00:09:11,584 How could you know? 142 00:09:12,185 --> 00:09:13,664 Everybody knows. 143 00:09:18,691 --> 00:09:19,829 (SIGHS) 144 00:09:19,893 --> 00:09:21,167 Radio One Asia. 145 00:09:21,928 --> 00:09:24,374 Move on to Corinthians. I'll catch up. 146 00:09:24,431 --> 00:09:25,842 (CHUCKLES) Yes. 147 00:09:26,199 --> 00:09:28,179 ELEANOR: We're looking forward to having you home. 148 00:09:28,501 --> 00:09:31,072 And your room is all ready for you. 149 00:09:31,938 --> 00:09:33,281 Thanks, Mum. 150 00:09:33,373 --> 00:09:35,080 But Rachel and I will be staying together. 151 00:09:36,209 --> 00:09:37,415 I see. 152 00:09:37,510 --> 00:09:39,251 Well, I'm having the house re-done. 153 00:09:39,579 --> 00:09:41,183 And it's not ready for guests. 154 00:09:41,514 --> 00:09:43,721 If Rachel comes, I think she might be more comfortable 155 00:09:43,783 --> 00:09:45,524 staying somewhere else. 156 00:09:48,288 --> 00:09:50,632 All right, sorry about that. I saved you a piece. 157 00:09:50,723 --> 00:09:53,397 You did, did you? A very small piece at that. 158 00:09:53,460 --> 00:09:54,632 Thank you very much. 159 00:09:55,462 --> 00:09:57,442 How's your mom? Everything okay? 160 00:09:58,598 --> 00:10:00,202 Couldn't be better. 161 00:10:01,234 --> 00:10:02,235 RACHEL: Hey, Mom, this one's kind of cute. 162 00:10:02,302 --> 00:10:04,407 What do you think? No! No! 163 00:10:04,471 --> 00:10:06,781 You can't wear that to meet Nick's Ah Ma. 164 00:10:06,873 --> 00:10:09,285 Blue and white is for Chinese funerals. 165 00:10:09,375 --> 00:10:12,754 Now this, this symbolizes good fortune and fertility. 166 00:10:14,314 --> 00:10:17,727 Great! I was really going for that "lucky baby maker" vibe. 167 00:10:17,917 --> 00:10:19,624 Hey! You're the one who asked for my help 168 00:10:19,719 --> 00:10:21,630 picking out a dress to meet Nick's family. 169 00:10:21,721 --> 00:10:23,325 It's only 'cause I hardly know anything about them. 170 00:10:23,823 --> 00:10:25,825 Every time I bring them up, Nick changes the subject. 171 00:10:25,959 --> 00:10:27,461 Maybe he's embarrassed. 172 00:10:27,794 --> 00:10:30,104 Maybe his parents are poor, and he has to send them money. 173 00:10:30,163 --> 00:10:31,836 That's what all good Chinese children do. 174 00:10:31,931 --> 00:10:35,572 (SCOFFS) You're going to have a wonderful time. 175 00:10:35,635 --> 00:10:37,410 You've always wanted to go to Asia. 176 00:10:37,804 --> 00:10:40,614 And who knows, if all goes well in Singapore, 177 00:10:40,673 --> 00:10:42,414 you might just come back with a souvenir. 178 00:10:42,475 --> 00:10:44,580 (SCOFFS) Mom, stop! 179 00:10:44,911 --> 00:10:46,515 Nick and I haven't even talked about that. 180 00:10:46,646 --> 00:10:49,024 (KERRY CHUCKLES) 181 00:10:49,115 --> 00:10:51,595 I mean, his parents can't not like me, right? 182 00:10:54,187 --> 00:10:55,962 What was that look? I saw that. 183 00:10:56,022 --> 00:10:58,696 Nothing. It's just, Nick 184 00:10:58,791 --> 00:11:00,793 bringing a girl all the way there to meet them 185 00:11:00,860 --> 00:11:03,841 can mean a lot to these overseas families. They're different from us. 186 00:11:03,930 --> 00:11:07,434 How are they different? They're Chinese, I'm Chinese. 187 00:11:07,967 --> 00:11:10,106 I'm so Chinese, I'm an economics professor 188 00:11:10,170 --> 00:11:11,615 with lactose intolerance. 189 00:11:12,105 --> 00:11:14,779 Yeah, but you grew up here. (SIGHS AND SPEAKS IN MANDARIN) 190 00:11:22,182 --> 00:11:23,320 (IN ENGLISH) You're different. 191 00:11:24,951 --> 00:11:28,524 But wearing a lucky color will make a good first impression. 192 00:11:29,189 --> 00:11:31,032 (INDISTINCT CHATTER) 193 00:11:34,894 --> 00:11:36,168 Okay, game plan. 194 00:11:36,796 --> 00:11:38,742 Check our bags, get through security and then 195 00:11:38,831 --> 00:11:42,244 we could eat one of the three homemade Tupperware meals my mom packed for us. 196 00:11:42,569 --> 00:11:44,310 Good afternoon, Mr. Young, Miss Chu. 197 00:11:44,370 --> 00:11:46,316 We'll take your bags and get you checked into first class. 198 00:11:46,506 --> 00:11:48,577 Great. Oh, no, there's a mistake. 199 00:11:48,675 --> 00:11:50,985 We're not first class. We're economy people. 200 00:11:51,211 --> 00:11:52,519 AIRPORT ATTENDANT: This way, please. 201 00:11:52,579 --> 00:11:54,490 Just go with it. Come on. 202 00:11:54,914 --> 00:11:55,915 But... 203 00:11:56,015 --> 00:11:58,052 Yeah, they'll be fine. Just leave them there. 204 00:12:02,088 --> 00:12:03,761 Welcome aboard, Mr. Young, Miss Chu. 205 00:12:04,357 --> 00:12:05,893 Here's the way to your private suite. 206 00:12:05,992 --> 00:12:07,437 (INDISTINCT CHATTER) 207 00:12:07,527 --> 00:12:09,165 And some champagne. 208 00:12:10,363 --> 00:12:11,603 (INDISTINCT ANNOUNCEMENT ON PA) 209 00:12:11,698 --> 00:12:13,041 Thank you. 210 00:12:16,736 --> 00:12:18,374 Thank you very much. You're welcome. 211 00:12:19,272 --> 00:12:21,548 After takeoff, would you like to enjoy the lounge chairs 212 00:12:21,608 --> 00:12:23,110 or should we convert your suite into a bedroom? 213 00:12:23,209 --> 00:12:24,347 Uh... 214 00:12:24,410 --> 00:12:25,787 We're good. Thank you. 215 00:12:26,346 --> 00:12:27,552 ATTENDANT: Enjoy. 216 00:12:29,282 --> 00:12:31,262 Nick. We can't afford this. Mmm. 217 00:12:34,220 --> 00:12:37,064 These pajamas are fancier than any of my real clothes. 218 00:12:37,957 --> 00:12:41,769 My family has business with the airline. The tickets, they're a perk. 219 00:12:43,263 --> 00:12:44,537 (UNZIPS BAG) 220 00:12:45,231 --> 00:12:46,266 What kind of business? 221 00:12:47,033 --> 00:12:50,742 Real estate, investment, other things. Nothing interesting. 222 00:12:50,970 --> 00:12:52,574 "Dim sum." 223 00:12:55,074 --> 00:12:57,714 So your family is, like, rich? 224 00:12:59,045 --> 00:13:00,080 We're comfortable. 225 00:13:01,281 --> 00:13:04,319 That is exactly what a super-rich person would say. 226 00:13:06,653 --> 00:13:09,827 It's not a big deal, obviously. I just 227 00:13:09,922 --> 00:13:12,562 think it's kind of weird that I had no idea. 228 00:13:13,226 --> 00:13:14,830 I mean, you have a Jamba Juice card. 229 00:13:15,295 --> 00:13:16,968 You use my Netflix password. 230 00:13:17,096 --> 00:13:19,599 You play basketball at that Y that kind of smells. 231 00:13:19,732 --> 00:13:21,678 I really like that place, thank you very much. 232 00:13:23,336 --> 00:13:26,909 And yes, my family has money, but I've always thought of it as theirs. 233 00:13:27,140 --> 00:13:28,141 Not mine. 234 00:13:28,608 --> 00:13:31,487 I get that. But I'm going all the way over there to meet them. 235 00:13:32,312 --> 00:13:34,417 Kind of just wanna know what I'm getting into. 236 00:13:34,480 --> 00:13:36,357 And, you know, they're your family. 237 00:13:36,516 --> 00:13:37,927 (SIGHS) 238 00:13:37,984 --> 00:13:39,327 Well... 239 00:13:40,853 --> 00:13:42,958 My family is much like anybody else's. Mmm-hmm. 240 00:13:43,022 --> 00:13:45,593 There's half of them that you love and respect, 241 00:13:45,958 --> 00:13:47,767 and then there's the other half. 242 00:13:48,261 --> 00:13:49,433 Which half am I meeting'? 243 00:13:50,997 --> 00:13:52,169 (YELLING) (SCREAMING) 244 00:13:52,265 --> 00:13:56,270 NICK: Well, there's my cousin Alistair, based in Taiwan, works in movies. 245 00:13:56,336 --> 00:13:58,043 (WOMAN CONTINUES SCREAMING) 246 00:13:58,137 --> 00:13:59,480 DIRECTOR: And cut! (BELL RINGS) 247 00:13:59,939 --> 00:14:03,477 NICK: He's dating Kitty Pong, an actress. 248 00:14:03,810 --> 00:14:05,153 Kitty. Alistair. 249 00:14:06,879 --> 00:14:13,489 You like it? I was feeling very, very the emotions. Can you feel it? 250 00:14:13,553 --> 00:14:16,363 Oh, I can feel all of you. And all of me. 251 00:14:16,456 --> 00:14:17,491 (KITTY MOANS) 252 00:14:18,291 --> 00:14:19,361 (IN MANDARIN) 253 00:14:29,869 --> 00:14:31,075 (IN ENGLISH) Okay, and what about your cousin Eddie? 254 00:14:31,170 --> 00:14:32,513 You don't ever talk about him. 255 00:14:32,739 --> 00:14:34,980 Well, Eddie's a big finance guy in Hong Kong. 256 00:14:35,308 --> 00:14:36,309 A real family man. 257 00:14:38,845 --> 00:14:40,552 (CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 258 00:14:40,646 --> 00:14:42,421 PHOTOGRAPHER: You know, if you move, it will look more natural. 259 00:14:42,515 --> 00:14:44,654 No, this way you get our optimal angles. 260 00:14:45,351 --> 00:14:47,194 (SIGHS) Then we're done. 261 00:14:47,320 --> 00:14:48,856 (INDISTINCT CHATTER) 262 00:14:48,921 --> 00:14:52,334 Russel, thank you so much. It's an honor to be photographed by you. 263 00:14:52,392 --> 00:14:55,498 My pleasure. People will love it in the next Hung Kong Vogue. 264 00:14:56,028 --> 00:14:58,008 Thank you, Russel. 265 00:14:58,598 --> 00:15:01,511 Hong Kong Vogue? I knew it. Your dress is a disaster. 266 00:15:01,567 --> 00:15:03,410 If you wore the Bottega gown like I told you to, 267 00:15:03,503 --> 00:15:04,504 we'd be in the American Vogue. 268 00:15:04,570 --> 00:15:06,447 You can wear that gown to Hell, Eddie. 269 00:15:06,539 --> 00:15:08,576 (TOY CARS HONKING) Stop! (YELPS) 270 00:15:08,674 --> 00:15:09,675 NICK: Then there's Astrid. 271 00:15:09,742 --> 00:15:11,744 Ah, I remember Astrid. 272 00:15:11,911 --> 00:15:13,515 She's like who l wanna be when I grow up. 273 00:15:13,846 --> 00:15:15,382 Astrid is awesome. 274 00:15:15,782 --> 00:15:17,591 And she's probably the only one I'm actually close with. 275 00:15:18,017 --> 00:15:19,587 And she's really grounded and down-to-earth, 276 00:15:19,685 --> 00:15:21,255 once you get to know her. 277 00:15:24,424 --> 00:15:26,097 (UPBEAT MUSIC PLAYING) 278 00:15:28,594 --> 00:15:31,131 NICK: Not only did she graduate top of her class at Oxford, 279 00:15:31,464 --> 00:15:34,411 start multiple charities, and is a fashion icon, 280 00:15:34,467 --> 00:15:37,607 Astrid has the biggest heart of any of my cousins. 281 00:15:39,405 --> 00:15:42,113 Mummy?
